reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central source of the essay’s optimism in section 3: that partial AM-convergence plus bargaining/trade can often get us close to a mostly-great future, illustrated via spatial/resource partitioning (e.g., ‘Milky Way vs other galaxies’) and more generally via separable “resource-compatible” compromises. If values are globally non-separable (lexical constraints like ‘no suffering anywhere’, uniqueness/non-duplication, universal-status rules, etc.), then simple carve-ups don’t preserve ‘most value’ for each side. However, the essay already partially anticipates this kind of problem via (i) discussion of limited resource-compatibility and ‘narcissism of small differences’, and (ii) extensive emphasis on negative-leaning/constraint-like axiologies and the fragility of trade under threats; so the objection is more a sharpening/extension than a full refutation. It also somewhat overstates the paper’s claim (the essay is conditional and uncertain rather than asserting trade straightforwardly implies mostly-great futures). Still, the point is coherent, clearly stated, and would require the essay to more explicitly model global constraints / governance rather than relying on tradable parcels.
title: Non-separable moral values make cosmic resource partitioning unworkable
